messageBody:
Quoth Scott Stirling:
> --- Steven Taschuk <staschuk@...> wrote:
[...]
> > Processes do not represent any real-world object;
> > they are entirely constructs of the model. The
> > question of faithfulness of representation doesn't
> > arise.
>
> I am a little on the fence with this example. You can
> explain that a process has a start and an end, ways of
> interacting with the environment, that they use
> resources, and are controlled, enabled or regulated by
> a larger system. In this sense, a software process
> could correspond to a natural process, like
> photosynthesis or blood clotting.

Certainly an analogy can be drawn, and it justifies the use of the
word "process". But it's a long step from that to the idea that
OS processes are intended to *model* real-world processes, which
is what is needed for faithfulness of representation to be an
important consideration.

An analogy can also be drawn between the kind of windows that let
you see through walls and the windows of windowing GUIs, again
justifying the word. But no one objects that GUIs' windows don't
get streaked and so are not faithful representations of their
real-world counterparts, nor that minimizing a window has no
real-world analogue and so is added behaviour that corrupts the
object design.

> > Resources often do represent real-world objects, but
> > it is highly desirable that the representations have
> > properties those objects do not -- sharability among
> > concurrently executing processes, for example.
>
> How do you represent "shareability" as a property in
> something like a software file? [...]

The example I had in mind was the printing system, actually,
construed as a representation of the printer. This system has
queueing behaviour which the printer does not, and as a result
printing more than one job simultaneously through the printing
system gives different (and more useful) results than trying to
print more than one job directly on the printer.

[...]
> I wonder if "changeability" could be reduced and made
> more precise by analysis, like I am trying to reduce
> "testability" and "maintainability." [...]

If you're just looking for a more precise definition, I'd suggest
this: a system is said to have high changeability when the cost of
changing it is low. (Still vague, but it's the proper vagueness.)

My claim that changeability is desirable relies on a tacit
assumption that the costs of change dominate the lifetime costs of
a software system. (Well, I also have aesthetic reasons for
liking changeability. But cost reduction is the main pragmatic
reason.)
